questions.question: The intrapleural pressure (cm of H2O) at the beginning of inspiration is around
questions.explanation: The normal intrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration is about -3.4 cm H2O (-2.5mmHg).Intrapleural pressure is the pressure of the fluid in the thin space between the lung pleura and thechest wall pleura. During normal inspiration, expansion of the chest cage pulls outward on thelungs with greater force and creates more negative pressure.At the peak of normal inspiration, it is about -8.15 cm H2O (-5.4 mm Hg).Note: 1mm Hg = 1.36 cm H2O373

questions.question: With reference to atmospheric pressure, what is the alveolar pressure at the end of normalinspiration (in cms of H2O)?
questions.explanation: At the end of inspiration, the alveolar pressure is zero with reference to the atmospheric pressure.Whenever alveolar pressure equals atmospheric pressure, alveolar pressure is said to be zero. Thishappens when no air is moving in or out of the lungs.During inspiration, the diaphragm contracts, causing the volume of the thorax to increase. As lungvolume increases, the pressure in the lungs must decrease. (Boyle's law states that P × V isconstant at a given temperature.) Halfway through inspiration, the alveolar pressure falls belowatmospheric pressure (-1 cm H2O). The pressure gradient between the atmosphere and the alveolidrives airflow into the lung. Air flows into the lungs until, at the end of inspiration, alveolarpressure is once again equal to the atmospheric pressure; the pressure gradient between theatmosphere and the alveoli has dissipated, and airflow into the lungs ceases.During expiration, alveolar pressure rises to about +1 cm of H2O.

questions.question: The transpulmonary pressure is the pressure difference between
questions.explanation: Transpulmonary pressure is intra-alveolar pressure minus intrapleural pressure. (MnemonicTAP: Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Pleural pressure)It is the pressure difference between that in the alveoli and that on the outer surfaces of the lungs,and it is a measure of the elastic forces in the lungs that tend to collapse the lungs at each instantof respiration, called the recoil pressure.Transpulmonary pressure:760 mm Hg -756 mm Hg= 4 mm HgIntrapleural pressure:756 mm Hg (-4 mm Hg)

questions.question: A 22-year-old woman has pulmonary compliance of 0.2 L/cm H2O and an alveolar pressureof 4 cmH2O and an intrapleural pressure of -5 cmH2O at the beginning of inspiration. What366is the transpulmonary pressure (in cmH2O) when this woman inhales 600mL of air?
questions.explanation: The transpulmonary pressure would be 12 cmH2O when she inhales 600mL of air.Transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) is the difference between alveolar pressure (Palv) and intrapleuralpressure (Pip). It is given by the formula: Ptp = Palv-Pip. Inspiration causes a negative change inboth the Palv and Pip. Lung compliance is the extent to which the lungs will expand for each unitincrease in transpulmonary pressure.In a normal adult, the pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O of both lungstogether. Hence, expanding the lungs by 200 mL of inspired air will require an increase in Ptp by1 cm H2O.Given:Pulmonary compliance = 0.2 L/cm H2O= 0.2 L/cm H2O = 200 ml/cm H20Alveolar pressure at the beginning of inspiration = 4 cmH2OIntrapleural pressure at the beginning of inspiration = -5 cmH2OVolume of air inhaled = 600mL (0.6L)Step 1: Calculate the initial transpulmonary pressure (Ptp).Transpulmonary pressure = Alveolar pressure - Intrapleural pressure; Initial transpulmonarypressure = 4 cmH2O - (-5 cmH2O) = 9 cmH2OStep 2: Use the lung compliance formula to find the change in transpulmonary pressure.Lung compliance = Change in volume / Change in transpulmonary pressure.Pulmonary compliance is 0.2 L/cmH2O or 200 mL/cmH2O. Hence, to expand the lungs by 200mL of inspired air, it will require an increase in Ptp by 1 cm H2O. So, for 600 ml inspired air, thecompliance is = 600 mL / 200 mL/cm H2O = 3 cmH2OStep 3: Calculate the transpulmonary pressure (Ptp) after inhaling 600mL of air.During inspiration, the alveolar pressure (Palv) decreases, and the intrapleural pressure (Pip)becomes more negative.Final transpulmonary pressure=Initial transpulmonary pressure + change in transpulmonarypressure; Final transpulmonary pressure = 9 cmH2O + 3 cmH2O = 12 cmH2O.375

questions.explanation: A liquid-ventilated lung is more compliant compared to a gas-ventilated lung.Compliance is a measure of distensibility. In a gas-filled lung, surface tension and elastic recoilforces act to collapse the lung and thus reduce compliance.Volume(% maximum inflation)10050Lung complianceDeflation10SalineAirHysterisis20Pressure (cm H2O)MARROWInflationN3040• When the lungs are filled with air, there is an interface between the alveolar fluid and the air inthe alveoli; so, there is surface tension.•• But, in the case of the saline solution-filled lungs, there is no air-fluid interface and there isno surface tension, making it more compliant.• Hence, the pressure-volume curve obtained with saline measures only the tissue elasticity.•The difference in the curves generated during inflation and deflation, termed hysteresis, is notpresent in the saline-generated curves.

questions.question: What is specific compliance of lung?
questions.explanation: Specific compliance is obtained by dividing compliance by functional residual capacity.Types of compliance:• Static compliance: It is measured at rest.• Dynamic compliance: It is measured during breathing. It considers airflowresistance or impedance into account. It is maximum in medium-sized bronchi..Specific compliance:• Lung compliance is volume-dependent.•• It is greater at low lung volumes than at high lung volumes. For this reason, the term specificcompliance is often used to denote compliance with reference to the original lung volume.• The total compliance of a normal person near the normal end-expiratory lung volume (functionalresidual capacity [FRC]) is about 0.1 L/cm H20.•The compliance of the lungs is about 0.2 L/cm H2O.Applied aspect:In case of emphysema, compliance is increased but specific compliance decreases (because FRC isseverely elevated).

questions.question: Work done in quiet breathing is (kg-m/min)_
questions.explanation: Work done in quiet breathing is 0.5 kg-m/min.Estimates of the total work of quiet breathing range from 0.3 up to 0.8 kg-m/min.The work of breathing can be calculated from the pressure-volume curve.380The value rises markedly during exercise, but the energy cost of breathing in normal individualsrepresents less than 3% of the total energy expenditure during exercise.Applied aspect:In the case of COPD, airway resistance increases (obstruction to outflow). Hence, the patientshould take slow, deep breathing.In the case of restrictive lung disease, viscous resistance increases. Hence, the patient is advisedrapid, shallow breathing.

questions.question: Work of breathing is mostly due to
questions.explanation: Most of the work of breathing is due to surface tension elasticity.Work of Breathing:• Elastic/Compliance work (65%): Surface tension (2/3rd) + Tissue elasticity (1/3rd)• Non elastic work (35%): Tissue/Viscus resistance (7%) + Airway resistance (28%)Work of quiet breathing = 0.3 - 0.8 kg-m/minMaximum work of breathing = 10kg-m/min

questions.question: The following diagram shows the depth of respiration of a 45-year old man who suffered ahead injury in an automobile accident. Identify the pattern of breathing.370Respiratory amplitude
questions.explanation: The pattern of breathing seen in the image is Cheyne-Stokes breathing. In this case, the personbreathes deeply for a short interval and then breathes slightly or not for an additional interval.This pattern repeats itself about every minute.It is the most common type of periodic breathing seen most commonly in patients with heartfailure and uremia, also seen in patients with brain disease and during sleep in normalindividuals.This increased response occurs apparently due to the disruption of neural pathways that normallyinhibit respiration. In such an individual, increased sensitivity to CO2 causes relativehyperventilation, lowering the arterial Pco2. During the resultant apnoea, the arterial Pco2 risesagain to normal, but the respiratory mechanisms again over-responds to CO2.
